pr_title: [NETBEANS-3986] Creating New Class On Pasting Class Text

timeline.message: [NETBEANS-3986] Creating New Class On Pasting Class Text

timeline.bodyText: This will show this action on all folder nodes? People working on non-Java projects may complain about that. Have you considered merging this with the ordinary Paste action? (Might only be feasible with the standard java/java.project.ui/src/org/netbeans/spi/java/project/support/ui/PackageView.java#createPackageView, but that might be OK.
timeline.author: lahodaj

timeline.bodyText: I am unclear why finding ExplorerManager is needed - isn't "context" enough? I.e. shouldn't be paste simply happen "under" the given DataFolder?
timeline.author: lahodaj

timeline.bodyText:
I wonder if it wouldn't be easier to let some (Java) parser parse the class, and analyze the output. Something as simple as:
((JavacTask) javax.tools.ToolProvider.getSystemJavaCompiler().getTask(...)).parse()
might give much better outcomes, and is unlikely to be problematic w.r.t. performance (parse is typically very fast). The only parameter that really needs to be filled in for getTask is the last one, and it may be a singleton list with a very simple JavaFileObject, like this one:

  
    
      netbeans/java/lib.nbjavac/test/unit/src/org/netbeans/lib/nbjavac/services/NBClassWriterTest.java
    
    
         Line 61
      in
      5f675e8
    
    
    
    

        
          
           private static class MyFileObject extends SimpleJavaFileObject { 
        
    
  


(Passing the "out" Writer and passing the output to "/dev/null" is probably a good idea, as well, but not needed for the functionality to work.)
As far as I can tell, the code here won't work if:
-there are any imports
-or annotations
-or the class is non-public
-or if the thing that is being pasted is an interface, enum, annotation type (or record)
-or if there's any other modifier for the class (not a big factor right now, as probably only "strictfp" could be here).
This feels unnecessarily limited.
timeline.author: lahodaj

timeline.bodyText:
Using:
File f = new File(path + "\" + className + ".java");// NOI18N
will clearly not work on Linux, and probably not on Mac - the file separator for these is '/'. I would suggest to simply using FileObject all the way, unless there is a really compelling reason to not to.
timeline.author: lahodaj

timeline.bodyText: This feels really weird - I don't think anyone ever said anything about the names of the Nodes. Suggest to use ClassPath.getClassPath(SOURCE, target).getResourceName(target) (handling failures along the way).
timeline.author: lahodaj
